entry.et: Middle English, from Old English; akin to Old High German balz belt; both from Latin balteus belt

def.dt: :a strip of flexible material worn especially around the waist as an item of clothing or a means of carrying something (as tools)
:a similar article worn as a corset or for protection or safety or as a symbol of distinction
:a continuous band of tough flexible material for transmitting motion and power or conveying materials
:an area characterized by some distinctive feature (as of culture, habitation, geology, or life forms)
:one suited to a particular crop the corn belt
:asteroid belt
:beltway 1
:unfair unfairly
:in one's possession :as part of one's experience
:to encircle or fasten with a belt
:to strap on
:to beat with or as if with a belt :thrash
:strike hit
:to mark with a band
:to sing in a forceful manner or style belting out popular songs
:to drink quickly belted down a shot of whisky
:to move or act in a speedy, vigorous, or violent manner
:to sing loudly
:a jarring blow :whack
:drink a belt of gin
:a singer with a powerful voice
:a reduction in spending
:shut up
:the region of interplanetary space between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter in which most asteroids are found
:an area chiefly in the southern United States whose inhabitants are believed to hold uncritical allegiance to the literal accuracy of the Bible
:an area characterized by ardent religious fundamentalism
:an area characterized by rich black soil
:an area densely populated by blacks
:one who holds the rating of expert in various arts of self-defense (as judo and karate)
:the rating itself
